revision_history.draft:
Ice cracks in the garden’s throat  
a hollow hymn  
frost peels back its silver skin  
revealing the bruise of stone  

water reclaims the cracks  
a tongue of silver  
siphoning through frozen soil  
carving paths where roots once whispered  

the earth’s slow exhale  
a rumble beneath the loam  
shadowed corners bloom  
with the faint hum of insect tunnels  
stirring  
unfrozen  
again

Ice cracks in the garden’s vein  
a hollow tune  
frost unfurls its silver skin  
revealing the scar of stone  

water reclaims the cracks  
a tongue of silver  
sipping through frozen soil  
carving paths where roots once murmured  

the earth’s slow exhale  
a rumble beneath the loam  
shadowed corners bloom  
with the soft hum of insect tunnels  
stirring  
unfrozen  
again

Ice cracks in the garden’s vein,  
a hollow tune—  
frost unfurls its silver skin,  
revealing stone’s scar.  

Water reclaims the cracks,  
a tongue of silver,  
sipping through frozen soil,  
carving paths where roots once whispered.  

The earth’s slow exhale—  
a rumble beneath the loam,  
shadowed corners bloom,  
soft hum of insect tunnels stirring,  
unfrozen,  
again.
revision_history.critique:
**What’s alive:**  
The poem captures the quiet, tactile process of thawing—

final_poem:
Ice cracks in the garden’s vein,  
a hollow hymn—  
frost unspools its silver skin,  
revealing stone’s scar.  

Water reclaims the cracks,  
a tongue of silver,  
sipping through the frozen soil,  
carving paths where roots once whispered secrets.  

The earth’s slow exhale—  
a rumble beneath the loam,  
shadowed corners bloom anew,  
soft hum of insect tunnels stir,  
unfrozen, again—  
a breath, a thaw, a beginning.
